STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 28, 2024
CHELSEA LYNN TUCKER
PATHWAYS OF ARBOR CIRCLE
412 CENTURY LN,
HOLLAND, MI, 49423-4285
RE: License#: CB700201042
Dear CHELSEA LYNN TUCKER:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 5/20/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB700201042
Licensee Group Organization: Arbor Circle Corporation
Licensee Designee: Kristin Lynn Gietzen
Chief Administrator: CHELSEA LYNN TUCKER
Name of Agency: PATHWAYS OF ARBOR CIRCLE
Agency Address: 412 CENTURY LN
HOLLAND, MI 49423-4285
Agency Telephone #: 6163962301
Original Issuance Date: 11/01/1992
Service Types: Place children for adoption, certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff
• (8) An agency shall employ or contract for a
sufficient number of competent staff to carry out
the provisions covered by these rules. The
workload for each staff member may not be
more than any of the following:
• (b) Fifteen children assigned to a social
services worker for purposes of providing
direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services
or a combination thereof.
Four of six social service workers were carrying more than 15 cases at the time of
inspection.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 5/30/2023, CAP Approved 6/8/2023
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing

agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (f) Documentation that the foster parent
has received orientation to the policies of
the borrowing agency.
One of three borrowed bed files reviewed contained documentation indicating the
family was orientated to the agency policies and procedures after placement
occurred.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (g) A copy of the foster parent /agency
agreement signed by the foster parent
and the borrowing agency.
One of three borrowed bed files reviewed contained documentation indicating the
family was provided with and signed the Foster Parent Agency Agreement after
placement occurred.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (4) Before completion of the written report
required by subrule (6) of this rule, an agency
shall provide the foster parent with a verbal
summary of the preliminary findings at the
conclusion of the evaluation.
One of two closed foster home files reviewed contained a special evaluation
report indicating the verbal summary was provided to family prior to the
conclusion of the investigation.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:

• (g) Recommendations regarding licensing
action and any required corrective action.
One of two closed foster home files reviewed contained two special evaluation
reports indicating the report was not completed within 15 days of investigation
conclusion.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following
in the child's record before a change of
placement occurs:
• (g) Information about the child was
shared with the new placement,
consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
One of eight open files of youth in foster care placement did not contain
documentation that all required information was provided to new placement
following a placement change.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of eight open files of youth in foster care placement contained a service plan
completed one day late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 6/1/2022, CAP Approved 6/6/2022

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (6) Service plans must be signed by the social
services worker and the social services
supervisor.
One of eight open files of youth in foster care placement did not contain Worker
and Supervisor signatures on all service plans.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
• (1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within 90
days of the family signing an adoption
application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
Three of three adoptive family evaluation reviewed were completed within 90
days after application was signed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 6/1/2022, CAP Approved 6/6/2022
Interim 5/30/2023, CAP Approved 6/8/2023
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement

or no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
Five of nine open youth files reviewed (8 foster care, 1 IL) did not meet all Family
Team Meeting requirements. The violations included semi-annual and service
plan development meetings not held timely and missing FTM paperwork.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 5/30/2023, CAP Approved 6/8/2023
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care
are placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:

• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case
Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan to review, and I will have the opportunity to
express my disagreement with the Case
Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the report
date.
Five of nine open youth files reviewed (8 foster care, 1 IL) did not meet all Parent
Agency Agreement signature requirments. The violation included missing
signatures or signatures obtained outside of the 30 day requirement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 6/1/2022, CAP Approved 6/6/2022
Interim 5/30/2023, CAP Approved 6/8/2023
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• No technical assistance was requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• No consultation was requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The one corrective action plan was submitted in response to the 5/30/2023
licensing interim inspection report and was approved on 6/8/2023. That CAP
addressed seven violations, four of which were not repeated during this year's
inspection. The three repeated areas of violation; adoptive family assessment
timeliness, FTM's and PATP signatures all increased in individual instances of
non-compliance. These violations will need additional corrective action planning to
address the ineffectiveness of the previous CAP.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment was completed thoroughly and submitted
timely. Areas of non-compliance identified were meeting service plan timeframes,
meeting adoptive family assessment timeframes, and maintaining caseload
compliance, all these areas of non-compliances were attributed to high staff
turnover over the past year, including workers who resigned within a few months
of hire and workers who gave little or no resignation notice. The chief administrator
also identified several areas of non-compliance with contract and DHHS policy,
none of which are regulated by DCWL.
Financial Overview
Financial documents reviewed included the agency's budget, financial summary,
financial statement, and independent auditors report. No financial concerns were
identified.
Staff Interviews
The staff members interviewed indicated it has been a tough year due to staffing
turnover and vacancies; however, all of the staff indicated receiving good support
and assistance from their immediate supervisors as well as upper management.
They all reported, despite having high caseloads, they are able to manage their
workload well.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space and equipment to ensure delivery of
foster care, independent living, certification, and adoption services. Case files and
physical CHRI is stored securely in locked cabinets within a locked file room that
cannot be accessed by unauthorized personnel.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No Safety Concerns Identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
May 28, 2024
_____________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 28, 2024
_____________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
